awd_titl_txt: MRI: Dynamic Micro-Computed Tomography for Multidisciplinary Research and Foundational Education of the Sciences
awd_abstract_narration:
This Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) award supports the acquisition of a dynamic micro-computed tomography instrument. Dynamic testing is essential for evaluating functionality over time. Micro-computed tomography techniques are non-destructive and provide 3D information at the micrometer scale. This project aims to integrate advanced research instrumentation in science and engineering with educational training for minority students. The micro-computed tomography instrument will be acquired by Florida A&M University (FAMU), a historically black college and university. The capability of the instrument provides an efficient characterization tool for examining many microstructured systems. It will be used in a range of research projects to conduct significant work in novel polymer-metal-ceramic composites, actuation mechanisms, bio-composites and macro-organisms, and fossilized creatures. The instrument will also help train students from multiple disciplines in the behavior of materials to produce the next generation of a STEM minority workforce. The instrument will also play an important role in the newly established Materials Science and Engineering graduate program. Additionally, this instrument will help FAMU establish the X-Ray Imaging Science Center and be part of the training network for the United States synchrotron facilities.

The procurement of a Rigaku Computed Tomography (CT Lab HX) system provides new research opportunities by scaling experimentation through nondestructive 3D imaging, critical for identifying key microstructural dynamic features. The CT500 is a 500N in-situ tensile/compressive stage. The integrated mechanical testing unit within the CT's available open-frame can achieve 10-20 mm, respectively, for compression or tension modes. This will enable application-specific testing across a multidiscipline basis to encompass varying scan times from seconds, minutes and processes occurring over an hour. FAMU will be the steward and will coordinate fundamental studies of novel interdisciplinary challenges. Fundamental research projects using the instrument address cross-campus needs that encompass studies of 1) multiarchitectured polymer material flow for functional fiber production and 4D printing; 2) physiological and morphological growth of common pests for the food-water nexus; and 3) enhanced computational image processing. By systematically investigating material structures at length scales where critical features can be detected, this instrument allows the research community to study innate mechanisms of a range of problems spanning structural, environmental, chemical, and organic-related processes. This project will also attract collaborations with regional industry, national laboratories, and municipal entities for public STEM engagement.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Florida A&M University/FAMU-FSU College of Engineering

por.por_cntn:
This Track 1 acquisition of the micro-computed tomography system (by Rigaku) resulted in positive synergistic outcomes and collaborations between different departments and entities at Florida A&M University. This state-of-the-art equipment played a major role in engaging the regional scientific community and training students in new analytical techniques. X-ray computed tomography (μ-CT) is a nondestructive imaging tool that generates high-resolution three-dimensional images by compiling two-dimensional projections of a specimen, with a resolution reaching ~2 microns. The system comprises three main components: a sample holder, a phosphor detector/CCD camera, and an X-ray source with a collimator that shapes the beam. The acquired instrument achieves high-resolution scans in ~20 minutes, with shorter times possible for smaller objects, enabling in-situ studies such as tensile testing and void formation for failure mode modeling. Factors influencing scan duration include: X-ray source voltage, Voxel size (resolution), Field of view (FOV), Scanning mode (continuous or step-wise), and number of projections. The acquisition of μ-CT capabilities not only met a need but also significantly enhanced our existing fundamental materials analysis techniques for exploring a wide variety of research that include intellectual merit. 

Research involved image processing on energy-hardened material structures, such as boron-nitride composites irradiated at different dosing levels. Nanocomposites containing fiber with sizes of approximately 8-12 microns were investigated, making  μ-CT  a suitable technique to analyze the composite's behavior under different stressors. This work also enabled cross-university partnerships with a Texas-based HBCU. 

Further work explored the multifunctional performance of scalable carbon nanotube (CNT) yarn laminate composites. Tensile, thermal, electrical, and electromagnetic interference (EMI) shielding properties were compared to state-of-the-art unidirectional carbon fiber composite (CFRP). We could demonstrate that our CNT laminates  proved comparable to CFRPs in strength through image-examination, but had superior thermal transport properties, over 13 times higher than the CFRP.

 Our  μ-CT techniques were used to analyze the morphology and physiology of insect species relevant to agricultural environments. The goal is to establish scanning parameters and evaluate the technique's potential for studies examining the impact of common pests on the food-water nexus, and how insect pests have adapted to the changing environment. Preliminary scans were conducted to determine optimal instrument settings for imaging insect samples that are preserved in a fluid. The Co-PI is planning further experimentation for his USDA catalog.


Broader Impacts: the equipment acquisition grant paved the way for FAMU to create the first user-facility. Few minority institutions possess the capability to perform micro-CT analysis, making this acquisition a transformative milestone. The MRI Acquisition grant enabled the implementation of strategic areas of interest FAMU’s Centers of Excellence and the FAMU-FSU College of Engineering in helping to establish the center for future scientific exploration. Within the past 2 years, the PI’s have helped to start the new Material Science and Engineering Department (inaugural faculty members) and have MOUs with national labs that will benefit from future knowledgeable workforce.  To date we have received 83 applications to participate in this program and experiment with the system in the upcoming academic cycle, demonstrating immediate demand and interest in this cutting-edge capability. Additionally, securing a staff line dedicated to facilitating this new research activity has significantly bolstered our ability to support advanced projects and collaborations.  

By integrating materials education and planned research involving the micro-CT system into the curricula of multiple departments, we aim to create a dynamic mechanism for motivating students, enhancing retention, and improving their scientific skills. Access to such advanced technology provides students with unparalleled opportunities to engage in unique scientific initiatives, fostering a deeper understanding of fundamental science while preparing them for careers in STEM fields.  We conducted a joint research experience for undergraduates summer internship, where 22 undergraduate students from around the country participated in scientific modules during a 10 week materials project.

The broader impacts of this initiative extend beyond individual student development. It positions our institution as a leader in micro-CT research and education within underrepresented communities, paving the way for innovative studies in materials science, biology, and engineering. Furthermore, this system represents a global first—Rigaku has never sold this specific configuration anywhere else in the world—underscoring the trailblazing nature of our program. By equipping our students and faculty with state-of-the-art tools, we are not only advancing local academic and research excellence but also setting a precedent for other institutions to follow.

 



Last Modified: 01/24/2025
Modified by: Theo Siegrist

por.por_txt_cntn:
This Track 1 acquisition of the micro-computed tomography system (by Rigaku) resulted in positive synergistic outcomes and collaborations between different departments and entities at Florida A&M University. This state-of-the-art equipment played a major role in engaging the regional scientific community and training students in new analytical techniques. X-ray computed tomography (-CT) is a nondestructive imaging tool that generates high-resolution three-dimensional images by compiling two-dimensional projections of a specimen, with a resolution reaching ~2 microns. The system comprises three main components: a sample holder, a phosphor detector/CCD camera, and an X-ray source with a collimator that shapes the beam. The acquired instrument achieves high-resolution scans in ~20 minutes, with shorter times possible for smaller objects, enabling in-situ studies such as tensile testing and void formation for failure mode modeling. Factors influencing scan duration include: X-ray source voltage, Voxel size (resolution), Field of view (FOV), Scanning mode (continuous or step-wise), and number of projections. The acquisition of -CT capabilities not only met a need but also significantly enhanced our existing fundamental materials analysis techniques for exploring a wide variety of research that include intellectual merit.


Researchinvolved image processing on energy-hardened material structures, such as boron-nitride composites irradiated at different dosing levels. Nanocomposites containing fiber with sizes of approximately 8-12 microns were investigated, making -CT a suitable technique to analyze the composite's behavior under different stressors. This work also enabled cross-university partnerships with a Texas-based HBCU.


Further work explored the multifunctional performance of scalable carbon nanotube (CNT) yarn laminate composites. Tensile, thermal, electrical, and electromagnetic interference (EMI) shielding properties were compared to state-of-the-art unidirectional carbon fiber composite (CFRP). We could demonstrate that our CNT laminates proved comparable to CFRPs in strength through image-examination, but had superior thermal transport properties, over 13 times higher than the CFRP.


Our -CT techniques were used to analyze the morphology and physiology of insect species relevant to agricultural environments. The goal is to establish scanning parameters and evaluate the technique's potential for studies examining the impact of common pests on the food-water nexus, and how insect pests have adapted to the changing environment. Preliminary scans were conducted to determine optimal instrument settings for imaging insect samples that are preserved in a fluid. The Co-PI is planning further experimentation for his USDA catalog.






Broader Impacts: the equipment acquisition grant paved the way for FAMU to create the first user-facility. Few minority institutions possess the capability to perform micro-CT analysis, making this acquisition a transformative milestone.The MRI Acquisition grant enabled the implementation of strategic areas of interestFAMUs Centers of Excellence and theFAMU-FSU College of Engineeringin helping to establish the center for future scientific exploration. Within the past 2 years, the PIs have helped to start the new Material Science and Engineering Department (inaugural faculty members) and have MOUs with national labs that will benefit from future knowledgeable workforce. To date we have received 83 applications to participate in this program and experiment with the system in the upcoming academic cycle, demonstrating immediate demand and interest in this cutting-edge capability. Additionally, securing a staff line dedicated to facilitating this new research activity has significantly bolstered our ability to support advanced projects and collaborations.


By integrating materials education and planned research involving the micro-CT system into the curricula of multiple departments, we aim to create a dynamic mechanism for motivating students,enhancing retention, and improving their scientific skills. Access to such advanced technology provides students with unparalleled opportunities to engage in unique scientific initiatives, fostering a deeper understanding of fundamental science while preparing them for careers in STEM fields.We conducted a joint research experience for undergraduates summer internship, where 22 undergraduate students from around the country participated in scientific modules during a 10 week materials project.


The broader impacts of this initiative extend beyond individual student development. It positions our institution as a leader in micro-CT research and education within underrepresented communities, paving the way for innovative studies in materials science, biology, and engineering. Furthermore, this system represents a global firstRigaku has never sold this specific configuration anywhere else in the worldunderscoring the trailblazing nature of our program. By equipping our students and faculty with state-of-the-art tools, we are not only advancing local academic and research excellence but also setting a precedent for other institutions to follow.
